title: Horrifying pictures reveal the filthy conditions pets were kept in by owner
text:
Maria Warren, 53, kept her two cats and dog in filthy conditions (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS.COM)

A woman has been banned from keeping animals for life after her pets were discovered living in a squalid, faeces-covered home.

Maria Warren, 53, kept her two cats Midge and Smudge and her dog Finlay in ‘awful’ conditions, with pictures showing rubbish piled high, discarded bottles lying around and thick layers of filth on every surface.

An examination by a veterinary surgeon concluded that Midge was suffering as he was underweight, with extensive fur loss, scabbing and live fleas.

Warren, from Pengegon, near Camborne, Cornwall, was given a warning on May 3, explaining that the needs of the animals were not being met in respect of their need to live in a suitable environment.

A further RSPCA investigation revealed that advice was not followed and access to the property was denied, leading to further concerns for the welfare of the pets.

Warren’s cat Midge was found to be underweight, with extensive fur loss, scabbing and live fleas (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS.COM)

Pictures of Warren’s house show rubbish piled high on the floor of the kitchen (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS.COM)

Thick layers of filth covered every surface in the property (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS.COM)

On June 7, a warrant was executed by police and the two cats and dog were rescued.

Warren was given a lifetime disqualification from keeping animals during a trial at Truro Magistrates’ Court in Cornwall.

The pet owner, who was not present in court, was also ordered to pay £300 and cannot appeal her ban for three years.

The court heard in mitigation that the care was well intended, but incompetent, and that the neglect of the animals was not deliberate.

RSPCA Inspector Paul Kempson said: ‘The ground floor living room and kitchen were extremely messy with what appeared to be bags of general rubbish covering all of the floor area to a depth of about two feet.

Finlay the dog was rescued along with two cats on June 7 (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS.COM)

Warren, from Pengegon, near Camborne, Cornwall was given a warning on May 3, but did not take the RSPCA’s advice (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS.COM)

The pet owner was banned from keeping animals for life and ordered to pay £300 (Picture: RSPCA /SWNS.COM)

‘This rubbish was also covered in what appeared to be cat and dog faeces in various places.

‘The kitchen was in a state of complete disarray with rubbish all over the floor, every work surface and the sink was piled high with unwashed dishes.

‘Throughout the ground floor there were many hazards for the dog and cats inside the property, including empty dog and cat food tins all over the place.

‘This case highlights how pet owners must follow advice, or seek help and support if they are struggling to cope with a situation they find themselves in.

‘By failing to do this, and by displaying incompetent care, these animals were found in these awful conditions.’

description: Cornwall woman Maria Warren has been banned from keeping animals for life after her pets were found living in squalid conditions.
